metadata.description:
Proba (project for on board autonomy) is the smallest earth observation satellite launched by ESA in 2001. Chris (compact high resolution imaging Spectrometer) is the most important imaging spectrophotometer on the platform of proba. It has five imaging modes. With its excellent spectral spatial resolution and multi angle advantages, it can image land, ocean and inland water respectively for different research purposes. It is the only on-board sensor in the world that can obtain hyperspectral and multi angle data at the same time. It has high spatial resolution, wide spectral range, and can collect rich information in biophysics, biochemistry, etc. At present, there are 23 scenes of proba Chris data in Heihe River Basin. 
The coverage and acquisition time are as follows: 4 scenes in Arjun dense observation area, 2008-11-18, 2008-12-05, 2009-03-29, 2009-05-22; 1 scene in pingdukou dense observation area, 2009-07-13; 7 scenes in Binggou basin dense observation area, 2008-11-19, 2008-11-26, 2008-12-06, 2009-01-10, 2009-03-04, 2009-03-30, 2009-03-31; dayokou basin dense observation area, 2009-07-13 There are two views in the observation area, 2008-10-23, 2009-06-08; one in Linze area, 2008-06-23; one in Minle area, 2008-10-22; seven in Yingke oasis dense observation area, 2008-04-30, 2008-05-09, 2008-06-04, 2008-07-01, 2008-07-19, 2009-05-31, 2009-08-10. 
The product level is L1 without geometric correction. Except that there are only four angles for the images of 2009-03-29 and 2009-05-24 in the Arjun encrypted observation area, each image has five different angles. 
The remote sensing data set of the comprehensive remote sensing joint experiment of Heihe River, proba Chris, was obtained through the "dragon plan" project (Project No.: 5322) (see the data use statement for details).

background: Leaf area index (LAI) is one of the important geometric-structure parameters in terrestrial vegetation ecosystems. Accurate LAI retrieval is always a key task of such remote-sensing applications, and it is also a precondition of crop-yield estimation, vegetative evapotranspiration calculation and the energy-exchange evaluation of terrestrial vegetation (Badhwar et al., 1986; Townshend et al., 1988; Baret et al., 1991; Wood et al., 1993; Bonan, 1995; Bicheron et al., 1999; Buermann et al., 2001; Kamalesh et al., 2008). In general, there are three categories of LAI retrieval methods. The first category is experiential inversion method based on Vegetation Index (VI), such as retrieving LAI according to the correlation between the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) and LAI (Turner, 1999; Brown et al., 2000; Haboudane et al., 2004; Wang et al., 2005). Although such an approach is simple and widely-used, its accuracy is very low, and some VI can easily get saturated. The second category can be called the reflectance model inversion method, by which the anisotropic effect caused by sun-object-sensor geometry can be removed, but the effect caused by background variations cannot be avoided, especially within mixed pixels. The complex background inhibits accurate LAI retrieval (Li et al., 1986; Nilson et al., 1989; Chen et al., 1997; Xu, 2005).
research objective: Based on a hybrid canopy reflectance model, a new hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) is proposed in this paper. This method can estimate LAI accurately through analyzing the canopy anisotropy. The study region was situated in Zhangye, Gansu Province, China; hyperspectral and multi-angular images of the study region were acquired via the Compact High-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer/Project for On-Board Autonomy (CHRIS/PROBA), on 4 June 2008.
challenges: The anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and variability in atmospheric conditions constitute three factors that can strongly constrain the accuracy of retrieved LAI. As the derivative method is very sensitive to random noise, we put forward an innovative filtering approach, by which the data can be de-noised in spectral and spatial dimensions synchronously.
methods: After the pre-processing procedures, the DSD method was applied, and the retrieved LAI was validated by ground reference data at 11 sites.
dataset: The study region was situated in Zhangye, Gansu Province, China; hyperspectral and multi-angular images of the study region were acquired via the Compact High-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer/Project for On-Board Autonomy (CHRIS/PROBA), on 4 June 2008.
findings: Results show that the new LAI inversion method is accurate and effective with the aid of the innovative filtering method.

Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is the use of the Compact High-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer (CHRIS) aboard the PROBA satellite, which captures hyperspectral and multi-angular images. This method was used in Zhangye, Gansu Province, China, as part of a study to estimate the leaf area index (LAI) accurately.

Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the anisotropy of canopy reflectance, along with variations in background characteristics and atmospheric conditions, which can constrain the accuracy of retrieved LAI. Addressing these factors is crucial for improving the precision of LAI estimations from remote sensing data.

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'hyperspectral and multi-angular images' in remote sensing data collection?
Definition.Answer: Hyperspectral and multi-angular images refer to data collected from sensors like the CHRIS/PROBA, which are capable of capturing images across a wide spectrum of wavelengths and from multiple angles. This allows for detailed analysis of the Earth's surface, capturing both the spectral and directional properties of reflected light.

Definition.Question: What does 'geometric-structure parameters' mean in the context of terrestrial vegetation ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: In the context of terrestrial vegetation ecosystems, 'geometric-structure parameters' refer to measurements like the Leaf Area Index (LAI) that describe the physical structure and arrangement of vegetation, which is crucial for understanding light interception, photosynthesis, and energy exchange processes.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of retrieving leaf area index (LAI) using the hyperspectral directional second derivative method compare to those faced by traditional methods based on Vegetation Index (VI)?
Comparison.Answer: Traditional VI-based methods, while simple and widely used, often suffer from low accuracy and saturation issues. The hyperspectral directional second derivative method, on the other hand, addresses these limitations by analyzing canopy anisotropy and offers improved accuracy. However, it also faces challenges such as sensitivity to random noise, which is mitigated by using an innovative filtering approach.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying factors could explain the high accuracy of LAI retrieval using hyperspectral directional second derivative methods when compared to other retrieval methods?
Interpretation.Answer: The high accuracy of LAI retrieval using hyperspectral directional second derivative methods can be attributed to its ability to analyze canopy anisotropy effectively, as it considers the directional reflectance properties and applies an innovative filtering approach to de-noise the data in both spectral and spatial dimensions, addressing issues of background variations and atmospheric conditions.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can multi-angular imaging data enhance the interpretation of terrestrial vegetation parameters compared to traditional single-angle approaches?
Interpretation.Answer: Multi-angular imaging data enhances the interpretation of terrestrial vegetation parameters by providing multiple perspectives that help in removing anisotropic effects caused by varying sun-object-sensor geometries, which can improve the accuracy of parameters like LAI by allowing for a more comprehensive analysis of the canopy structure.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in retrieving the Leaf Area Index (LAI) using hyperspectral data in remote sensing applications?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and variability in atmospheric conditions are factors that strongly constrain the accuracy of retrieved LAI. Additionally, the derivative method used in these applications is very sensitive to random noise.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to use multi-angular images in analyzing terrestrial vegetation ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Using multi-angular images helps in accurately estimating the Leaf Area Index (LAI) by analyzing the canopy anisotropy, which is crucial due to the complex interactions of light with vegetation structures.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) for LAI retrieval on the accuracy of vegetative evapotranspiration calculations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of the hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) for LAI retrieval can lead to accurate estimations of LAI by analyzing canopy anisotropy. This accuracy in LAI retrieval is a precondition for precise vegetative evapotranspiration calculations, suggesting an improvement in the accuracy of such calculations.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does addressing the anisotropy of canopy reflectance impact the retrieval of accurate LAI in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Addressing the anisotropy of canopy reflectance impacts the retrieval of accurate LAI by removing the anisotropic effect caused by sun-object-sensor geometry. This allows for more precise LAI estimation even in the presence of complex background variations, which are common in heterogeneous landscapes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of implementing an innovative filtering approach for de-noising data in both spectral and spatial dimensions on the data quality?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing an innovative filtering approach for de-noising data in both spectral and spatial dimensions can significantly enhance data quality by reducing random noise. This leads to more reliable data, which is essential for accurate LAI retrieval and subsequent analyses.

Goal Orientation.Question: What drives the need for innovative filtering approaches when working with hyperspectral datasets in terrestrial ecosystem research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Innovative filtering approaches are needed to de-noise data in both spectral and spatial dimensions simultaneously, which is vital because the derivative method used for LAI estimation is very sensitive to random noise.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are used to address the challenges of canopy reflectance anisotropy and background variability in data collection for hyperspectral and multi-angular imaging?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The challenges of canopy reflectance anisotropy and background variability are addressed by employing a new hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) that analyzes canopy anisotropy. Additionally, an innovative filtering approach is applied to de-noise the data in both spectral and spatial dimensions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are hyperspectral and multi-angular images preprocessed to ensure accurate biophysical parameter retrieval in remote sensing applications?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Hyperspectral and multi-angular images undergo preprocessing procedures to prepare the data for analysis. This includes applying the DSD method and validating the retrieved parameters such as LAI with ground reference data to ensure accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the simultaneous acquisition of hyperspectral and multi-angular data in remote sensing applications?
Enablement.Answer: The Compact High Resolution Imaging Spectrometer (CHRIS) on the PROBA satellite enables the simultaneous acquisition of hyperspectral and multi-angular data due to its exceptional spectral and spatial resolution and multi-angle capabilities.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the use of multi-angular remote sensing data enhance the estimation of vegetation parameters such as the Leaf Area Index (LAI)?
Enablement.Answer: Multi-angular remote sensing data enhances the estimation of the Leaf Area Index (LAI) by allowing for the removal of the anisotropic effects caused by sun-object-sensor geometry, thus improving the accuracy of LAI retrieval.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to collect accurate Leaf Area Index (LAI) data using remote sensing techniques in varied atmospheric conditions?
Expectation.Answer: The anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and variability in atmospheric conditions can strongly constrain the accuracy of retrieved LAI. These factors introduce complexities that affect the remote sensing measurements.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for the high expectation of using hyperspectral and multi-angular images for enhancing the accuracy of biophysical parameter retrieval?
Expectation.Answer: Hyperspectral and multi-angular images, such as those acquired by the Compact High Resolution Imaging Spectrometer/Project for On-Board Autonomy (CHRIS/PROBA), offer enhanced spectral and spatial resolution that can provide more detailed information about the canopy anisotropy, which is crucial for accurate biophysical parameter retrieval.

Expectation.Question: Why might a new hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) be expected to improve LAI estimation compared to traditional methods?
Expectation.Answer: The new hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) is proposed to accurately estimate LAI by analyzing canopy anisotropy. This method is expected to overcome the limitations of traditional methods, such as the sensitivity to random noise, through an innovative filtering approach that de-noises data in spectral and spatial dimensions synchronously.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using the hyperspectral directional second derivative method for LAI retrieval, and how might they be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The hyperspectral directional second derivative method faces challenges such as canopy reflectance anisotropy, background variability, and atmospheric conditions, which can affect LAI retrieval accuracy. These challenges may be addressed through innovative filtering approaches that de-noise data in both spectral and spatial dimensions, enhancing the reliability of results.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the techniques used to validate the data collected from hyperspectral and multi-angular images in the context of leaf area index (LAI) estimation.
Assertion.Answer: The techniques used to validate the data collected include ground reference data at specific sites. The retrieved LAI from the hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) was validated by ground reference data at 11 sites, ensuring accuracy and effectiveness.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the challenges faced in data collection for accurate retrieval of leaf area index (LAI) using remote sensing techniques.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in data collection for accurate retrieval of LAI using remote sensing techniques include the anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and variability in atmospheric conditions. These factors can strongly constrain the accuracy of the retrieved LAI, making it difficult to obtain precise measurements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the effectiveness of a new hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) in estimating LAI in complex environments.
Request/Directive.Answer: The new hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) is effective in estimating LAI in complex environments. It accurately analyzes canopy anisotropy and is validated by ground reference data at 11 sites. The results demonstrate the method's accuracy and effectiveness, especially with the aid of an innovative filtering approach that de-noises data in spectral and spatial dimensions.
